comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Gosh, those eyes! She's listed in a play by Philip Barry in 1928, although that might be a bit late. A few more roles in the 1930s follow en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holiday_(play) "Hope Williams, New York society girl, has her first starring role." There are also a few society listings in the 1910s of Hope Williams as a bridesmaid. Not an altogether uncommon name, so it's hard to tell if it's her.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: I'm seeing Hope Waldron Williams as a debutante in fall 1915; her married older sister threw a luncheon for her in November 1915: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0810F9395D16738... There's also a wedding announcement in 1922, for Hope Waldron Williams ("Junior League member and amateur actress") and R. Bartow Read, married at her sister's house in Rye NY. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20815FF3C5D1A7A9... R. Barton Read (d. 1931) was part of the "Millionaires' Unit" from Yale, during WWI : www.millionairesunit.org/index.php?option=com_content&...

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: It's definitely her, there's a photo of her in Holiday on this page: thegreatkh.blogspot.com/2012/06/holiday-1938.html She died in 1990. www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/obituaries/hope-williams-92-ac...

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: The NYPL has some photos of her as well digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?th-62447 and they have a bunch from "Holiday"
